quoteLast: ’, and that it may possibly have occurred as early on the day of Caesar’s landing. This admission throws a breaking strain upon his theory; but by dint of dexterous manipulation of the facts he is just able to make a show of saving it from ignominious collapse.
title: Ancient Britain and the Invasions of Julius Caesar
author: Holmes, T. Rice (Thomas Rice), 1855-1933

quoteFirst: after high water; and the duration of the westward stream, on one of the two occasions on which he observed it, was only 5 h. 53 m.[2994] According to these data, if, on the day of Caesar’s landing, high tide had occurred at
quoteLast: , the westward stream might have ceased at 3.4 p.m. It would have been impossible for Lewin, if he had been required to take account of this statement, to deny it. But to admit it would have been to sign the death-warrant of his own theory.
title: Ancient Britain and the Invasions of Julius Caesar
author: Holmes, T. Rice (Thomas Rice), 1855-1933

title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 05, November 1884, No. 2
